text.p: These are the leading stories in the Egyptian press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel stresses to Egypt Germany's concern with stability in the region and its rejection of Israeli settlement building. Kinkel and President Hosni Mubarak meet in Luxor to discuss Middle East peace and increasing the role of Europe in the process.
- Egyptian Foreign Minister Amr Moussa says that Egypt will make its position known on the Israeli-Turkish military exercises after their aim is clear.
- Joint Moroccan-Egyptian committees headed by Mubarak and King Hassan will meet in Rabat in the coming week to discuss efforts to rescue the peace process and bilateral economic ties.

- Press spokesman at U.S. embassy in Cairo denies reports that annual economic aid to Egypt will be cut. This aid was $815 million. The official said it would remain at the same levels as in previous years.
- Mubarak will meet Colombian President Ernesto Samper Pizano in the Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh today.
- International donors pledged $2.5 billion in aid to Egypt during Enterprise Minister Atef Obeid's visit to Paris.
- Today is a holiday for the private sector on the occasion of the Islamic new year. Banks and the Cairo stock market also have the day off.

- Consultative council starts its debate on Saturday on the federal budget for 1997/98 and it will pass on its report to the president on Wednesday. The federal budget aims to shrink the cost of living for nationals. The budget is 83 billion pounds.
- Mubarak held talks about the peace process and other issues with Ireland's agriculture minister Ivan Yates in Luxor on Wednesday.
